Award.AwardTitle: UTRAC: Using Technology to Research After Class

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Advancing Informal Science Learning Pathways project, Using Technology to Research After Class (UTRAC), explores whether a combination of technology (e.g., iPad-enabled sensors, web-based inquiry-focused portal) and facilitated visits improves learning outcomes for rural and Native American elementary-age youth in after school programs. Expected outcomes include improved engagement, knowledge, skills, and attitudes toward science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Project goals include promoting STEM learning through science inquiry activities keyed to specific Next Generation Science Standards as well as improving how technology can be used to enhance learning outcomes in afterschool programs. The experimental design of this project - testing the effects of physical or virtual facilitation visits on learning outcomes - will lead to improvements in STEM learning outcomes among rural and underrepresented students.

This project will employ several innovations in utilizing technology to teach STEM topics including: (i) hands-on, real-time, crowd sourced data collected by participants in their schoolyards; (ii) a pedagogic emphasis on communication of schoolyard data among and between participants; (iii) testing of motivational incentives; and (iv) partnerships between after school providers, preservice teachers, and university researchers as facilitators. The entire process will be modularized so that it can be modified in terms of place, STEM topic or student cohort. The topic focus of the project -- Life Under Snow -- is relevant to participating students, as Montana school playgrounds lie blanketed under snow for the majority of the school year; it includes elements of snow science, carbon cycle science, and a combination at the intersection of three recent literacy initiatives (e.g., Earth Science, Climate, or Energy). UTRAC will pilot and evaluate facilitated snow science/carbon cycle science activities that couple real-time schoolyard data with tools patterned after those available through WISE (Web-based Inquiry Science Environment; wise.berkeley.edu). Participants will collect and compare data with other youth participants, and researchers will use formative assessments to define interventions with potential to maximize student engagement and learning improvements among underserved youth. The project will advance understanding of informal education's potential to improve STEM engagement, knowledge, skills and attitudes by quantifying how - and to what extent - youth engage with emerging technologies iPad-enabled sensors, and crowdsourcing and visualization tools. The deliverables include a quantifying metric for learning outcomes, a training model for the iPad sensors and web application, an orientation kit, a social media portal, and database for the measurements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the use of a carbon cycle-based curriculum, the UTRAC team explored whether sensor technologies (e.g., thermal imagers, carbon dioxide meters) or assessment technologies improved student learning outcomes in informal STEM learning (ISL) contexts. We focused on rural and Native American elementary- and middle-school-age youth in three types of ISL settings: single-day enrichment programs (Figure 1, above), multi-week after-school programs (2015-2016), and one-week summer camps (2015-2017).

Our first two years, UTRAC relied on ~70 undergraduate preservice teachers enrolled in a University course to implement multi-week programming at nine schools across four semesters that reached ~700 non-unique participants.  UTRAC team members (faculty, staff, or a Ph.D. student [A. Obery]) also implemented 10 single-day (~150 unique participants) and five, week-long summer camp programs (~200 unique participants). Participants were generally Grades 3-8. UTRAC team members additionally participated in multiple community science nights on the Blackfeet Indian Reservation.  

Our overall results suggested the following:

(i) Field experiences provided preservice teachers with valuable opportunities to gain practical experience contending with issues related to technology integration, instructional planning, classroom management and attendance, all within ISL contexts. Deliverable: Lux et al. 2017.

(ii) After-school activities with game-like approaches and physical activity; connections with participants’ prior knowledge; and hands-on explorations improved the apparent engagement, enjoyment, and knowledge gain of participants (n=212).  Deliverable: Grimberg et al. (in revision for resubmission).

(iii) Across four summer camps (2016-2017), each with about 75 middle school students, our two indices of cognitive engagement (cognitive strategies, self-regulation) and two indices of motivation (value, self-efficacy) together predicted student aspirations in science such as taking high school courses or pursuing careers in the sciences.  An initial analysis of our camp engagement and content knowledge data was also presented by Obery at the 2018 International Conference of the Association for Science Teacher Education. Deliverables: Obery et al. (in revision for resubmission), cognitive engagement and motivation survey instrument.  

(iv) Our final year, we compared the software platforms of Kahoot, Nearpod, and Plickers for engagement and content knowledge data collection and learned there might be unexpected tradeoffs between these platforms.  Across seven site visits to local schools or camps in 2017, we tested specific educational activities and documented student reactions to differing assessment platforms through focus group interviews, 3rd party observations, and self-report surveys.  Any ‘novelty effect’ associated with innovative assessment platforms appeared short-lived, with some students appearing to become fatigued by high frequency assessments.  Furthermore, competitive platforms like Kahoot can lead to some students focusing on “winning” (selecting any response) instead of “learning” (by selecting the correct response).  We caution practitioners that even minimal assessments could interfere with the spontaneity, flexibility, and ‘informality’ of these informal STEM learning contexts.  Deliverable: An analysis of these tradeoffs will be presented at the Society of Information and Technology Education Conference in Washington in March 2018.

As outlined in our proposal, we intended to spark student interest in and knowledge about the carbon cycle in informal STEM learning contexts--in measurable ways.  In the context of educational assessment, it has been said that what is important cannot be measured.  Our findings provide evidence to the contrary.  We have advanced informal STEM learning, and, in that spirit, we close with a handful of student quotes:

“I learned the name of methane is CH4. I think it was really fun to learn about combustion by burning stuff with magnifying glasses.”

“That people, even produce carbon dioxide. we breath it out but the plants breath it in.”

“I learned that carbon travels to pretty much everything. Soil, plants,  oceans, the sky, animals, people, fossil fuels, rocks, and plastic. Plus, magnifying glasses burn things quickly.”

“I learned that dry ice is made out of carbon dioxide that has been compressed with lots of energy so that the molicules don't move, and it turns into solid.”

“I learned the different gasses that are in the breath you take in.like you take more oxygen when you breathe In , but when you breathe out you exhale more carbon dioxide”

“I learned that we inhale mostly nitrogen more than any other gas. I also learned that our breathe is kind of acidic.”

“I learned that even if you cant see something, that doesn't mean that it doesn't make a change in the temperature. I saw this with the thermal guns.”

“I will tell my dad that carbon dioxide has increased in the last 100 years.”

“I learned that your idea might not work the first time so. You have to try again. Also that c20 can blow up a balloon”
